subject: Re: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
msgSnippet: In rMock we used the following contruct: public void testSomething() {
messageBody:
In rMock we used the following contruct:

public void testSomething() {
<code that we don't expect to throw an exception>
expectThatExceptionThrown(isInstanceOf(SomeException.class));
<code that we expect to throw an exception>
}

I think that idea is what Charlies assertThrows suggestion hinted towards.

While this freedom can be abused it allows to precisely pinpoint what should
throw an exception. Also, you could do all kind of hamcrest checks on the
exception instance that is not possible to do with annotations. The
underlying implementation in the rMock-case is that
expectThatExceptionThrows primes the framework with an expection that any
exception is checked against before the exception is rethrown as an error
(if the check passes the Exception is expected and not rethrown).

Jusr my 5 cents :)

> > Kent, I agree that it is expected behavior, technically. I think you
